Spectroscopic characterization–catalytic activity correlation of molybdena based catalysts H. Al-Kandari b A.M. Mohamed a S. Al-Kandari a F. Al-Kharafi a G.A. Mekhemer c M.I. Zaki c A. Katrib a ⁎ a Chemistry Department, Kuwait University, P.O. Box 5969 Safat 13060, Kuwait b College of Health Sciences, PAAET, P.O. Box 1428, Faiha 72853, Kuwait c Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Minia University, El-Minia 61519, Egypt ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +965 24985582; fax: +965 24816482. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Hydrogen reduction of MoO3 produces MoO2 structure of metallic properties. ► Brønsted acid MoOH groups were formed on the surface. ► Consequently, a bifunctional MoO2−x (OH) y catalyst is formed on the sample surface. ► XPS–UPS, ISS and FT-IR spectroscopic techniques enable to characterize this system. ► Alkali K metal addition suppresses the Brønsted acid MoOH functions. ► Catalytic reactions of 1-hexene and n hexane were investigated on both systems. Titania-supported molybdena catalyst was prepared by calcination at 773K of ammonium heptamolybdate-impregnated TiO2 pellets with the equivalent of 5 monolayers of MoO3. Then, potassium-modified versions of the catalyst were prepared at 0.5–5wt%-K. The modified and unmodified catalysts were characterized, before and after H2-reduction at 673K, by means of ISS, XPS, UPS and FT-IR spectroscopy techniques. Results obtained enabled revealing the presence of density of states (DOS) at the Fermi level and, hence, metallic properties related to the deformed rutile structure of MoO2. On the other hand, Brønsted (MoOH) acidic function was found to form on the surface of the MoO2 structure, thereby producing a metal-acid (bifunctional) MoO2−x (OH) y catalyst. The presence of Brønsted acid MoOH groups was evidenced by in situ IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine molecules. On the other hand, the K-modification was found to enhance the molybdena dispersity and reducibility, but to suppress the surface acidity by transforming the bifunctional MoO2−x (OH) y species into the monofunctional MoO2−x (OK) y species. Subsequent catalytic measurements employing hydrotreating reactions of 1-hexene and n-hexane could confirm the exposure of bifunctional or monofunctional sites on the catalysts tested. The combination of research methods adopted in the present investigation has shown competency in unravelling the nature of active sites on heterogeneous catalysts. Keywords Catalytic properties of MoO2−x (OH) y MoO2−x (OK) y XPS UPS ISS FT-IR MoO3 TiO2 Bifunctional catalyst 1-Hexene n-Hexane 1 Introduction Identification of the active sites in heterogeneous catalytic processes constitutes a major challenge. The complexity of the situation results from the fact that catalytic active sites are formed, in situ, under specific activation condition(s). Moreover, the chemical structure of the catalyst is composed, quite often, of several elements having variable oxidation states. Also, the catalytic reaction takes place on the outermost surface layer, which is not necessarily similar to the bulk structure. In general, catalysts are classified as metallic, acidic or bifunctional (metal-acid). In this respect, we have developed bifunctional catalysts based on Mo and W oxides [1–3]. The catalytic active sites are formed throughout the hydrogen reduction of MO3 (M=Mo or W) at temperatures up to 673K in the case of MoO3. Initial activity is triggered following the reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 phase, which has metallic properties. The metallic character of MoO2, measured as density of state (DOS) structure at the Fermi-level, is rationalized in terms of delocalized π-electrons above Mo atoms placed along the c-axis of the deformed rutile structure of this phase [4,5]. Formation of Brønsted acid MoOH sites on the surface is effected following dissociative chemisorption of hydrogen molecules during the reduction process. Consequently, the reduction of MoO3/TiO2 leads to the formation of metallic-and-acidic (bifunctional) structure along the MoMo atoms, which is depicted as being MoO2−x (OH) y /TiO2. TiO2 is used as a support material for the catalysts thus generated in order to improve their surface accessibility and mechanical strength. The most adequate XPS–UPS, ISS, FT-IR, HRTEM and XRD spectroscopic techniques are implemented to identify the occurrence of the metallic and acidic functions on this catalyst system. On the other hand, well-established catalytic isomerization reactions undertaking the conversion of light linear C5–C7 hydrocarbon compounds into more valuable branched isomers are facilitated via the bifunctional mechanism [6]. These reactions take place in a concerted mechanism requiring the availability of both metallic and acidic functions. In contrast, hydrogenation of alkenes to alkane compounds requires the availability of metallic function only. Therefore, the present investigation was designed to apply above-mentioned spectroscopic techniques at similar experimental conditions, at which the catalyst conduct in the hydrogenation of 1-hexene and the isomerization of n-hexane is activated. The prime objective of the investigation is to correlate the catalyst surface structure, activity and selectivity, in hopes of a better understanding of the nature and type of the active site(s) in view of its optimization. Moreover, conclusions drawn are consolidated by spectroscopic observation of changes conceded by the sought correlations as a result of potassium-modification of the catalyst [7]. The exposure of different acid sites on TiO2-supported molybdenum oxides has been reported by several authors and research works [8,9]. Miyata et al. [8] did probe the presence of different Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on TiO2-supported molybdena via IR spectra of adsorbed ammonia or pyridine. It is postulated that relatively strong Mo n+ Lewis acid sites are converted to Brønsted type acid sites following the exposure to water vapor atmosphere. On the other hand, pure titania with or without water pretreatment did not show any Brønsted acidity by the adsorption of ammonia or pyridine [8]. It is noteworthy that the required bifunctional (metal-acidic) properties for the hydroisomerization of alkane molecules, as performed by MoO2−x (OH) y /TiO2, takes place only after the formation of the metallic function in MoO2, following hydrogen treatment of MoO3/TiO2 at higher temperatures than 573K. Such catalytic activity has not been observed using helium gas for example. In other words, the metallic function seems, in this case, to be the initial state for the dissociation of hydrogen molecules into active hydrogen atoms, which are then bonded to surface oxygen atoms of MoO2 to generate MoOH Brønsted acid sites. Just to mention that water pretreatment is not required in this case. Nevertheless, the formation of different Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on MoO3/TiO2, before and after hydrogen (and helium) treatments at different temperatures has been further probed in the present investigation, employing a combination of catalytic test reactions of 1-hexene and n-hexane, and surface characterization by XPS–UPS, ISS and in situ FTIR techniques. To the best of our knowledge, this combination of research techniques has not been adopted in such a single literature report. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported MoO3/TiO2 catalyst system was prepared by calcination at 773K for 12h of wet impregnated titania pellets with the equivalent of 5 monolayers of MoO3 of ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 99.9% pure product of STREM). The impregnation was carried out according to Pines et al. [10] and the titania support was Degussa P25 (75% anatase) with pore volume of 0.5cm3/g and BET surface area of 50±5m2/g. It is worth mentioning that, the loaded ammonium heptamolybdate was quantitatively decomposed into MoO3 species during the calcination process. For simplicity, the calcination product is denoted MoTi. The set of potassium-modified MoTi catalysts was prepared by post-impregnation of the dried heptamolybdate-impregnated TiO2 pellets with different concentrations of KNO3 prior to the eventual calcination process at 773K. The potassium concentrations used were calculated to amount to 0.5, 1, 2.5 and 5% of the molybdena content of the catalyst. The K-modified catalysts thus obtained are denoted x-KMoTi, where x stands for the %-K. In situ reduction of portions of the pure and K-modified catalysts thus obtained was carried out by heating at 673K for 12h of the catalyst in a flow of 40cm3 H2/min. The hydrogen gas was a 99.9% pure product of KOAC (Kuwait). 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB-250Xi spectrometer. The radiation source was monochromatic of AlKα operating at the power of 300W (15kV, 20mA). Ultraviolet Photoelectron Spectroscopy (UPS) He(I) resonance 584Å radiation of 21.217eV was employed for the Valence Band (VB) energy region measurements. Vacuum in the analysis chamber was better than 7×10−9 mbar during all measurements. The in situ reduction was carried out in a high-pressure gas cell housed in the preparation chamber. Binding energies were based on the carbon contamination C1s at 284.8eV within an experimental error of ±0.2eV. Ion scattering spectroscopy (ISS) measurements were performed on the same test sample using He+ with a kinetic energy of 1KeV. Ex and in situ Fourier-transform Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded at 4000–400cm−1 by averaging 200scans at the resolution of 4cm−1, using a Genesis II Thermo Mattson FT-IR spectrophotomer (USA) powered with a WinFirst Lite software (Mattson Corp.) for data acquisition and handling. The ex situ spectra were taken of lightly loaded (<1wt %) KBr-supported discs of the test materials. Whereas, the in situ spectra were taken of thin (30mg/cm2), but intact, self-supporting wafers of the test samples mounted inside a specially designed IR-cell equipped with CaF2 windows, before and after adsorption of pyridine (Py) molecules. Difference spectra of irreversibly adsorbed Py species were obtained by absorption subtraction of background spectra, facilitated by the installed software. 2.3 Catalyst tests Catalytic hydrotreating reactions of 1-hexene and n-hexane were studied on the test catalysts by introducing the reactants as pluses of 5μL and time on stream modes over a fixed-bed quartz reactor under atmospheric hydrogen pressure. A continuous H2 flow of 40cm3/min was allowed through 500mg of the catalyst, which contains 65mg of Mo. The reaction mixture was separated and analyzed with an on-line gas chromatograph Chemito, India 1000 equipped with a Petrocol-DH column and a flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 ISS spectra The impregnation of the equivalent of 5 monolayers of MoO3 on titania pellets seems to have been inhomogeneous as could be inferred from the display of O, Mo and Ti peaks in the ISS spectrum obtained for the calcined MoTi sample (Fig. 1a). This implies that MoO3 deposition is, most probably, in form of aggregates and not uniformly spread on the support surface [11]. Extensive research work has been reported in the literature concerning the dispersion of Mo oxide on different types of titania [9,12,13] by oxygen chemisorption. Chary et al. [9] did observe that in the case of loading below 6wt%-MoO3, molybdenum oxide particles disperse better on TiO2 (anatase) than on TiO2 (rutile). Moreover, the dispersed Mo oxide is present in the form of an isolated tetrahedral coordination environment on TiO2 (rutile), whereas the dispersion is in the form of polymeric species on TiO2 (anatase) [12]. The different states of dispersion are attributed to the different dehydration orders of OH groups of the molybdena and surface OH groups of the rutile and anatase. It is important to note at this point, that BET-surface area measured for the equivalent of five monolayers of MoO3/TiO2 was 34m2/g before reduction with hydrogen, which increased up to 48m2/g after reduction at 673K for 12h. This reduction by hydrogen corresponds to the activation procedure of the catalyst. The surface area of the catalyst is thus still less than that (50m2/g) of the pure TiO2 support. These results may explain the reason why titanium atoms are part of the outermost surface area as measured by ISS. The exact reason(s) of the absence of complete coverage of the TiO2 by the equivalent five monolayer of MoO3 could be attributed to the formation of a “para-crystalline MoO3” phase that resembles bulk MoO3 and takes the form of needle-like crystallites growing away from the support surface as postulated by Bond et al. [14]. Apparently, the interaction between molybdenum oxide and titania surface is less than in the case of in situ evaporated Mo atoms over TiO2. In the latter case, one monolayer equivalent of Mo(0) was sufficient to completely cover the titania surface as observed by Hercules et al. using ISS technique [11]. The display of an extra peak assignable to potassium in the spectra given rise by 1%- and 5%-KMoTi indicates that K atoms are also part of the outermost surface composition of the test samples (Fig. 1b and c). Subsequent in situ exposure of the test samples to hydrogen at 673K for 12h did not cause any change to the ISS spectra shown in Fig. 1. These results may reveal that the outermost surface of the test catalysts is composed possibly of one or more different chemical entities containing Mo, O, Ti and K. Accordingly, identification of the possible chemical species of the outermost surface before and after reduction using XPS–UPS and FT-IR techniques is essential in order to elucidate the sought catalyst surface structure-activity relationship(s). 3.1.2 XPS–UPS spectra XPS is the adequate surface analytical technique to gain information about the nature of chemical species established on the test surface. Monitoring changes conceded by the oxidation state of the ISS-identified Mo, O, Ti and K atoms (Fig. 1), before and after hydrogen-reduction is essential to define the surface chemical composition(s). Moreover, the presence of metallic function(s) is manifested by density of states (DOS) structure at the Fermi-level in the XPS–UPS valence band (VB) energy region. Reference XPS binding energies for the Mo (3d5/2, 3/2) are: 232.65 and 235.85eV for MoO3, 231.7 and 234.9eV for Mo2O5, 229.1 and 232.3eV for MoO2 and 227.7 and 230,85eV for Mo(0) [14]. On the other hand, Ti(2p3/2,1/2) binding energy values are observed at 458.5 and 464.2eV for TiO2 [15]. XPS Ti(2p) spectra obtained for pure TiO2 support, before and after H2-reduction at 673K for 12h, are quite similar in monitoring two well-defined spectral lines at 458.5 and 464.2eV (Fig. 2a). The two peaks are thus due, respectively, to Ti(2p3/2) and Ti(2p1/2) spin-orbit components of TiO2 [15]. Compatibly, in situ IR spectra taken of the TiO2, before and after reduction, are almost identical (Fig. S1, in the linked Supporting Information File). These results are consistent with literature data [16] showing that H2-reduction of TiO2 to lower valance state(s), such as Ti2O3, does commence at temperatures no less than 1273K. This may be correlated with our previous observation [17] demonstrating that TiO2 has no detectable catalytic activity in hydrotreating reactions of alkanes. On the other hand, The Ti(2p) peak broadening and binding energies remained invariant in XPS spectra obtained for MoTi and x-KMoTi before and after reduction (Fig. 2). XPS of the Mo(3d) energy region spectrum obtained for calcined MoTi (Fig. 3a) monitor two well-defined spectral lines at 232.65 and 235.85eV characteristics of Mo(3d5/2,3/2) spin-orbit components of MoO3 [14]. In situ sample exposure to hydrogen at 673K for 12h results in partial reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 [3] as could be observed from the peaks resolved at 232.5 and 229.6eV (Fig. 3b). However, the reduction process seems to be incomplete, because two peaks are additionally resolved at 233.9 and 231.7eV, which are assignable to the occurrence of Mo2O5-like species. It is most likely that, the Mo2O5 is formed as an intermediate surface species in the reduction course of MoO3 to MoO2 [18,19]. The formation of MoO2 as a result of this reduction process is also observed in the XRD of the reduced sample. It is interesting to note that for the same initial amount of MoO3 on TiO2, the extent of reduction to MoO2 is increased with the amount of potassium additive (0.5–5%; Fig. 3c and d). Apparently, substantial reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 is shown to take place following the modification with 5%-K (Fig. 3d). XPS K(2p) spectra obtained for the x-KMoTi catalyst samples (x =0.5–5%) (not shown), before and after reduction, were similar in monitoring two peaks at 292.9 and 295.7eV due, respectively, to K2p3/2 and K2p1/2 spin-orbit components. These peaks account for KO bond formation [20] in surface species such as KOMo. The possible formation of isolated molecular species in this case could result in better dispersion of the modified KMoTi structure. Consequently, a better reduction of Mo(VI) on the x-KMoTi samples (Fig. 3c and d) is expected as compared to the case on the unmodified MoTi sample (Fig. 3b). XPS of the VB energy region obtained for the calcined, K-modified and unmodified catalyst samples do not show any DOS structure at the Fermi level (Fig. 4 a). However, a pronounced DOS structure, characteristic of the metallic properties of MoO2, is observed in the spectra obtained following the samples in situ exposure to hydrogen at 673K for 12h (Fig. 4b–d). These spectra reveal, moreover, that the intensity of the DOS peak increases with the potassium proportion (Fig. 4b–d). This correlation is most probably related to the concomitant increase of the MoO2 proportion (vide supra). High-resolution UPS measurements facilitated resolving two maxima at 0.4 and 1.4eV for the observed DOS peak (Fig. 5 ). These energy values are assignable, respectively, to delocalized π-electrons (metallic function) above the MoMo atoms and σ-bonds between MoMo in the MoO2 structure [4,5]. 3.1.3 FT-IR spectra Several ex and in situ IR spectra were taken of the various test catalyst samples before and after irreversible adsorption of pyridine (Py) molecules. The obtained ex situ spectra are compared in Fig. S2. Based on relevant spectral data reported by Stencel [21], Massoth [22], and Gadsden [23], the set of ex situ spectra displayed in Fig. S2 may disclose that the molybdena load of the calcined MoTi is partly aggregated into MoO3 particles, whereas the rest is dispersed in the form of 2-dimensional structures constituting molybdate monomers and polymers. The modification with potassium additives is shown to increase the fraction of the monomeric species. Compatibly, Martin et al. [7] have found potassium additives to interact with MoO3/TiO2 at 773K leading to the formation of monomeric species of K2MoO4 and polymeric K2Mo4O13. The ex situ spectra (Fig. S2) show, moreover, that MoO3 is more easily reduced when dispersed on the TiO2 support than when it is self-supported bulk phase under the conditions applied, and that the potassium modification seems to further improve its reducibility. In situ IR spectra were taken of the calcined and reduced pure TiO2 support, MoTi, KMoTi and unsupported MoO3 before and after Py adsorption. The spectra obtained are given in Figs. S3–S6. The outcome of the information communicated by these spectra could justify drawing the following conclusions: (i) dispersion of molybdena species on the titania support develops the surface Lewis acidity by exposing Mo6+ sites, and generates strong Brønsted acidity via exposed Mo6+ OH groups, (ii) potassium additives weaken both the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites observed on the MoTi catalyst, which may be attributed to formation of potassium molybdate interaction species whereby MoOH groups are turned into MoOK groups, and (iii) H2-reduction of MoTi decreases proportions of the strong Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, whereas it eliminates the acid sites on KMoTi. The IR results in support of these conclusions are reviewed in Fig. 6 . The spectrum obtained for Py/MoTi at RT monitors two absorptions at 1636 and 1536cm−1 for the formation of pyridinium ions [24], thus revealing the presence on MoTi of strong Brønsted acidic sites (viz., MoOH). On the other hand, potassium-alkalization of MoTi (i.e., formation of KMoTi) is shown to weaken these two absorptions as a function of the amount of the potassium additive (1–5%-K). The observed easier thermal desorption of pyridine bound to Brønsted acid sites on KMoTi than MoTi at 473K (Fig. 6), and the increase of this easiness with the amount of the potassium additive, may lend a strong support to the XPS results suggesting formation of MoOK bonds at the expense of the acidic MoOH groups. It is worth noting that, the reduction of 5%-KMoTi rendered the material surface incapable of irreversibly adsorbs pyridine molecules at RT. This latter result indicates beyond doubt that the generated surface is void of strong Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. 3.2 Catalytic measurements Formation of the bifuctional (metal-acid) MoO2−x (OH) y surface species on the reduced MoTi catalyst and the modification(s) brought about by K additives (x-KMoTi catalyst) were assessed by testing the catalytic activity and selectivity of the respective catalysts in hydrotreating reactions of 1-hexene and n-hexane. The results obtained are rationalized below in terms of the availability of acidic, metallic, or dual metal-acid catalytic functions on the test catalysts. 3.2.1 1-hexene reactions Hydrogen reduction of MoO3/TiO2 at 673K for 12h generates the metal-acid bifunctional MoO2−x (OH) y surface species. Introduction of 1-hexene reactant on this surface result on 100% conversion of 1-hexene at all reaction temperatures probed (473–675K, Fig. 7 ). Fig. 7 reveals that at the temperature of 473K the complete conversion of the reactant encompasses 84.2% hydrogenation to n-hexane and 15.8% to saturated branched products, leading essentially to the formation of 2- and 3-methyl pentanes (MPs) to the thermodynamically controlled ratio (i.e., 2-MP/3-MP=1.5). Fig. 7 shows, moreover, that at 623K the conversion of 1-hexene gone to 59.9% MPs, 21.9% n-hexane, 12.9% hydrocracking C1–C6, and 5.3% iC4-iC5 products. At higher reaction temperatures, relatively higher amounts of the hydrocracking products are favored. This may be ascribed to thermodynamic and kinetic considerations. It is worth noting that, at near ambient reaction temperatures only the hydrogenation of 1-hexene to n-hexane takes place. The above results may be explained as follows. The hydrogenation of 1-hexene to n-hexane, which is catalyzed by the metallic function of MoO2−x (OH) y at relatively low reaction temperatures, seems to adopt the easiest surface reaction pathway. On the other hand, the 1-hexene branching to 2- and 3-MP is suggested to be undertaken via the following concerted multi-step process: (i) hydrogenation of 1-hexene to n-hexane, (ii) dehydrogenation of the formed n-hexane to 1-hexene [both step-(i) and -(ii)] are catalyzed by the metallic function of MoO2−x (OH) y , (iii) isomerzation of 1-hexene to i-hexene via carbenium ion mechanism facilitated by the Brønsted MoOH acidic function of MoO2−x (OH) y , and (iv) hydrogenation of the i-hexene isomers to i-C6 saturated isomers, which is catalyzed by the metallic function of the bifunctional active surface species. The catalytic steps (ii)–(iv) are known as the bifunctional mechanism of the isomerization reactions of alkane compounds [6]. Different catalytic behaviors were exhibited towards 1-hexene following the addition of increasing amounts of K to MoTi (i.e., the formation of x-KMoTi catalysts) and the subjection to the same hydrogen reduction process at 673K for 12h. The relative effect of the K proportion (0.5–5%-K) is visualized by the 1-hexene conversion product distributions at 623K as displayed in Fig. 8 . Irrespective of the amount of the K-additive, a complete conversion of 1-hexene molecules is observed. However, the product distribution is varied with the K-proportion. For instance, 31.0% selectivity to MPs formation and 62.0% hydrogenation to n-hexane are shown to occur on the 0.5%-KMoTi catalyst. This is to be compared with the occurrence of 2% selectivity to MPs formation and 93.4% hydrogenation to n-hexane on the 5%-KMoTi catalyst (Fig. 8). The above results may be explained as follows. At low reaction temperatures, all of the 1-hexene molecules are catalytically hydrogenated to n-hexane on the surface metallic function. The same situation applies to the subsequent dehydrogenation process (step-(ii)) observed to occur on the unmodified MoO2−x (OH) y (i.e., the reduced MoTi catalyst). As a matter of fact, isomerization of the produced n-hexane via the carbenium ion mechanism necessitates the co-existence of Brønsted MoOH acidic function. Consequently, the observed decrease in the production of MPs as a function of the amount of K-additive (Fig. 8), must be related to a consequent decrease in the population of Brønsted MoOH acidic sites. Hence, both MoO2−x (OH) y and MoO2−x (OK) y species should co-exist on the 0.5%-KMoTi catalyst, on which 31.0% MPs are produced (Fig. 8). Whereas, the observed complete suppression of the formation of MPs on the 5%-KMoTi should be correlated with an almost complete absence of the Brøønsted MoOH group of MoO2−x (OH) y in favor of the formation of MoO2−x (OK) y species. These catalytic results are in complete agreement with the above presented and discussed IR results. 3.2.2 n-Hexane reactions According to the above discussed catalytic results, it is expected that isomerization reactions of n-hexane take place only on the reduced MoTi (i.e., MoO2−x (OH) y /TiO2 catalyst). On the other hand, K-modified MoTi catalysts should not show catalytic activity towards n-hexane isomerization, especially on the 5%-KMoTi catalyst, on which almost all of the strongly acidic MoOH groups are converted into MoOK groups. Indeed, the onset of the catalytic activity of MoTi is observed at 573K, at which temperature the conversion of 39.1% n-hexane is observed to encompass 97.5% isomerization selectivity to the formation of MPs and di-methyl butanes (Fig. 9 ). The conversion of 72.7% n-hexane with isomerization selectivity amounting to 84.4% is observed to occur at 623K (Fig. 9). These relatively high conversion and isomerization selectivity of n-hexane are explicable by the availability on the reduced MoTi catalyst of the bifunctional (metal-acid) MoO2−x (OH) y species. On the contrary, the conversion is decreased to 20.2% and the isomerization selectivity to 78.9% when the reaction was conducted on 0.5%-KMoTi at the same temperature of 623K (Fig. 10 ). On 0.5%-KMoTi the MoO2−x (OH) y species are partly converted to MoO2−x (OK) y . Thus, the observed catalytic inactivity of the 5%-KMoTi towards n-hexane at 623K (Fig. 10) may signify that almost all of the strong Brønsted MoOH groups present in the MoO2−x (OH) y surface species are transformed into MoO2−x (OK) y . In other words, the absence of exposed strongly acidic MoOH groups renders the KMoTi catalyst inactive in isomerization reactions of n-hexane. 4 Conclusion Combination of XPS–UPS, ISS and FT-IR spectroscopic studies in parallel with catalytic measurements, carried out following the application of the same in situ pretreatment, enable identifying the catalytic active sites exposed on partially reduced MoO3 bulk or dispersed particles on TiO2. A bifunctional (metal-acid) surface species, represented here as MoO2−x (OH) y structure, is formed following the H2-reduction at 673K for 12h of the equivalent of 5 monolayers of MoO3/TiO2. The presence of the metallic function is monitored by XPS–UPS spectra showing a DOS structure at the Fermi level. The availability of the acid function (Brønsted MoOH groups) is IR-probed by the observance of two νCCN absorptions at 1636 and 1536cm−1 diagnostic for the formation of pyridinum ions (PyH+) on Brønsted acid sites. K+ ion additives transform the bifunctional MoO2−x (OH) y /TiO2 catalyst into a monofunctional (metallic) catalyst by converting the associated Brønsted MoOH groups into the inactive MoOK groups, as probed by the suppression of the IR diagnostic absorptions of adsorbed PyH+ ions. Furthermore, the potassium-modification improves the dispersion and reducibility of MoO3/TiO2, as evidenced by XPS measurements. The generation of the metal-acid bifunctional surface species (MoO2−x (OH) y ) and its K-assisted conversion into the metal monofunctional metallic MoO2−x (OK) y species is probed by catalytic activity and selectivity measurements towards hydrotreating reactions of 1-hexene and n-hexane. Only hydrogenation reactions of 1-hexene (metallic function catalyzed) are observed on the potassium-modified MoO2−x (OK) y /TiO2, i.e. the, x-KMoTi catalysts, whereas hydrogenation and isomerization reactions producing 2- and 3-methyl pentanes are observed for 1-hexene on the K-free bifunctional MoO2−x (OH) y /TiO2 (MoTi) catalyst. Using n-hexane as a reactant, only isomerization reactions to methyl pentanes take place on the MoO2−x (OH) y /TiO2 catalyst, whereas no catalytic activity is shown by x-KMoTi catalyst towards n-hexane molecules. coredata.dc:description: Titania-supported molybdena catalyst was prepared by calcination at 773K of ammonium heptamolybdate-impregnated TiO2 pellets with the equivalent of 5 monolayers of MoO3. Then, potassium-modified versions of the catalyst were prepared at 0.5–5wt%-K. The modified and unmodified catalysts were characterized, before and after H2-reduction at 673K, by means of ISS, XPS, UPS and FT-IR spectroscopy techniques. Results obtained enabled revealing the presence of density of states (DOS) at the Fermi level and, hence, metallic properties related to the deformed rutile structure of MoO2. On the other hand, Brønsted (MoOH) acidic function was found to form on the surface of the MoO2 structure, thereby producing a metal-acid (bifunctional) MoO2−x (OH) y catalyst. The presence of Brønsted acid MoOH groups was evidenced by in situ IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine molecules. On the other hand, the K-modification was found to enhance the molybdena dispersity and reducibility, but to suppress the surface acidity by transforming the bifunctional MoO2−x (OH) y species into the monofunctional MoO2−x (OK) y species. Subsequent catalytic measurements employing hydrotreating reactions of 1-hexene and n-hexane could confirm the exposure of bifunctional or monofunctional sites on the catalysts tested. The combination of research methods adopted in the present investigation has shown competency in unravelling the nature of active sites on heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Spectroscopic characterization–catalytic activity correlation of molybdena based catalysts
